newsitem.title: USA: Montgomery Ward gets permission to pay severed workers.
newsitem.headline: Montgomery Ward gets permission to pay severed workers.

text.p: Montgomery Ward & Co Inc., seeking to repair a black eye it received after stopping severance payments to fired employees, was granted permission Friday by a bankruptcy court to restart the payments.

The retailer, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Monday, said in court documents that it had suffered "substantial negative publicity" over the halt in payments, which total $3.9 million to 380 former workers.
The 408-store retailer also stopped paying pension benefits of $51,000 a month to widows of non-executive retirees, it said in documents filed in Wilmington, Del.
After a hearing in Wilmington, Bankruptcy Judge Peter Walsh granted the company's request to resume the payments.

Montgomery Ward said it was prohibited from cutting the checks under bankruptcy law. While it intended to ask the court for permission to resume paying again at a later date, it said Friday it needed an order to begin right away.

"In short, without the requested relief, the stability of the debtors would be undermined by the potential threat that otherwise loyal employees at all levels would seek other employment," the retailer said in documents.

The 408-store chain has eliminated 400 jobs at its corporate headquarters and closed three stores and two distribution centres this year. It plans to shut a third facility and a fourth store this summer.

The 125-year-old retailer filed for bankrutpcy protection after talks with lenders over a rescue package failed. Montgomery Ward employs about 50,000 workers. General Electric Co.'s GE Capital Services owns 58 percent of Montgomery Ward.
In Chapter 11 a company is protected from its creditors as it tries to work out a plan to pay its debts.
